data.name: Simple API
data.description:
Your task is to implement a simple API class. Your class will be responsible for handling registration and logins for a web application.

Your class will be passed two arguments to its constructor, ```client_id``` and ```client_secret```.

```client_id``` is the public identifier of your application, and is an 8 character hex string.

```client_secret``` is the secret key to your application, and is a 16 character hex string.


Both ```client_id``` and ```client_secret``` will need to be known by users to authenticate with your application.

Your class will distribute ```access_tokens``` to users who successfully authenticate with your application, and these tokens last exactly```3600``` seconds. To determine if a particular ```access_token``` has expired, your class will need to maintain an internal clock.


To that end, you will need to implement the ```simulate``` method:

```simulate``` accepts a single argument, ```seconds```, that will increment the internal clock of your API, and will be used to determine if any of the ```access_tokens``` that have been distributed so far have expired. ```seconds``` will always be a positive integer. Assume that your internal clock initialises to 0, and only increments when the ```simulate``` method is called.



You also need to implement ```receive_authentication_request```. This method will receive a single argument, ```authentication_request```. ```authentication_request``` will be a dictionary containing the following fields:

    {
        client_id: The public identifier of your application.
        client_secret: The secret key of your application.
    }

If the ```client_id``` and ```client_secret``` in the request match the ```client_id``` and ```client_secret``` passed to your API's constructor, your method should return an ```access_token```, which must be a ```32 character hex string```. If neither the ```client_id``` nor the ```client_secret``` match, return an empty string ```""```.


Any ```access_token``` your API distributes lasts at most ```3600``` seconds.

The hex strings received by the constructor, in addition to the ```access_token``` returned by the ```receive_authentication_request``` method, are case sensitive.

The third method to implement is```receive_registration_request```.

This method will receive a single argument, ```registration_request```. ```registration_request``` will be a dictionary containing the following fields:

    {
        access_token: A 32 character long hex string.
        username: The username selected by the user.
        password: The password selected by the user.
    }

You will need to perform some validation against the fields in ```registration_request```.

```access_token``` should be a valid token. By valid, it must be a token that was returned by the ```receive_authentication_request``` method within the last```3600``` seconds.

```username``` must be a strictly alphanumeric string, between 8-12 characters in length (both inclusive).

```password``` must be a strictly alphanumeric string, between 8-15 characters in length (both inclusive), and include at least:
```
- One upper case letter.
- One lower case letter.
- One number.
```

If any of the input validations fail, or ```username``` has already been successfully created in a previous registration request, your method should return ```False```. Otherwise, return ```True```.


The fourth and final method you need to implement is ```login```. ```login``` takes two arguments, ```username``` and ```password```. If the ```username```/```password``` combination has been successfully created, your method should return ```True```. Otherwise, it should return ```False```.


Note:
- All input will be valid:
  - Only dictionaries, with the keys outlined in the description, will be passed to both ```receive_authentication_request``` and ```receive_registration_request```. You only need to worry about the values.
  - Your ```simulate``` method will always be passed a positive integer.
- A hex string is simply a string containing characters in ```'0123456789ABCDEFabcdef'```.
